sections.title: Software
sections.content:
Dell offers in-house Linux support for a subset of hardware, contributing to the dell-smm-hwmon kernel module (refer to it's documentation here[1]) and providing native Linux utilities to control hardware on supported devices. These utilities include:

- libsmbios a suite of programs for controlling hardware. Key programs include: smbios-battery-ctl: Get and set battery charge configuration smbios-keyboard-ctl: Control keyboard backlight illumination and light sensors smbios-lcd-brightness: Set separate screen brightness for battery and mains smbios-sys-info: Get and set service, asset and property tags smbios-thermal-ctl: Get and set thermal modes - usually balanced, cool-bottom, quiet, and performance smbios-wireless-ctl: Get and control the status of radio hardware
- dell-command-configureAUR (cctk) enables BIOS configuration from userland. On some devices this is the only method for configuring and persisting custom battery charge behaviour.

- smbios-battery-ctl: Get and set battery charge configuration
- smbios-keyboard-ctl: Control keyboard backlight illumination and light sensors
- smbios-lcd-brightness: Set separate screen brightness for battery and mains
- smbios-sys-info: Get and set service, asset and property tags
- smbios-thermal-ctl: Get and set thermal modes - usually balanced, cool-bottom, quiet, and performance
- smbios-wireless-ctl: Get and control the status of radio hardware

ACPI platform_profiles are natively supported on newer kernels which enables setting thermal modes without Dell specific software.[2]

Dell also makes firmware updates for some devices available via the Linux Vendor firmware Service (LVFS).
